intro: Psilogramme incisa, commonly known as the narrow-leaf psilogramme, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. It is native to regions of southern Africa, particularly South Africa, where it thrives in rocky, well-drained soils. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with a slender, upright stem and small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels. Its foliage is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory properties. The species is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
